title: What will be China's year-on-year GDP growth rate for the first quarter of 2020?
preds: Who knows how the numbers will be presented. Normally when bad news is expected......the bad is overloaded so the next quarter looks better. Not sure if this strategy will be used in this case.
Well, they claim to have grown manufacturing sector despite all this. SO, I presumed they would cook the books but not so brazenly.
China appears to be going back to work in Q2. Lets hope that Europe and the US follow.

Considering a 50% hit to one month of China's GDP for Hubei province and tourism, and simply no growth for the entire China GDP for one month but following trend of 5.8% increase for the remaining two months brings the growth rate well below 4%
Things in China are looking up. Should do better in Q2.
Becuase of the current economic challenges, it will be lower than %4.0

Between the New Year and the corona crisis and data from other stats it's hard to imagine it being above 4%. "China International Capital Corporation has sharply downgraded its 2020 growth forecast for China to 2.6 per cent, from 6.1 per cent in January" - https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3076745/coronavirus-chinas-2020-growth-forecast-slashed-surprise-move

Forecasts:
Barrons: 4% to 5% (Feb 13) [0]
JP Morgan: -4% (Feb 26) [1]
Goldman: -9% (Mar 17) 2.5% (Feb) [2]
Reuters poll of 40 economists: 3.5% (median, with a range of 0% to 5.5%) (Mar 3-5) [3]
Fitch: 1.8%-4.% (Mar 18) [4]
China International Capital Corporation: 2.6% (Mar 23) [5] Quite a broad range of forecasts, especially surprising how negative Goldman and JPM are, although these initial estimates took place near the peak of COVID-19 in China. Trend growth was about 5% without coronavirus impact.  So +1.7% for January, then about -20% for February.  Partial recovery in March but to below the 1/1/2020 level.  Hence negative.  Even with manipulation of data, almost no chance that reported growth could be above 4% from 2019 level

The growth will be less as compared to last years rate, but there was a lag into Q1 that meant not everything was shut down.  Expect lover but not really low

With travel and industry ground to a halt, and the restrictions coupled with the trade war, I think that even though GDP is a solid number without breaking too much despite epidemics like SARS in 2003 which shed a bit off, I think this will be more intense.

From Foreign Policy link above: "most analysts reach back to the 2003 SARS outbreak, which knocked off an estimated 1 percent or more from China’s growth rate"
Me: China's growth rate doesn't shed pct points easily (stable system)
China had to take draconian measures to contain the outbreak. So, I do expect a significant drop compared to last year - perhaps in the range 3-4%.
this is very possible as shipping is extremly delayed.

Chinese economic data was worst than previous forecast.

- if we see more data out of NBS and China itself indicating willingness to report accurate figures will shift < 4% bucket up...
I expect optimistic reporting,  but that aside we should still see a slowdown in supply side, demand will start to dissipate as Covid-19 impacts the west.

Negative growth predicted by almost all major analysts.

https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/17/reuters-america-goldman-cuts-q1-gdp-estimate-for-china-sees-9-percent-contraction-vs-2-point-5-percent-earlier.html

Goldman forecast - 9% for Q1 https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-china-toll/goldman-sees-chinas-economy-shrinking-9-in-first-quarter-amid-coronavirus-outbreak-idUSKBN21340T ING also revised down to 3.6% https://think.ing.com/articles/china-downgrade-gdp-and-yuan-forecast-from-double-hit-of-global-supply-and-demand/ Still less pessimistic than crowd because of my beliefs about how Chinese govt reports and uses these numbers

In Q4 2019, China's GDP growth was reported at the lowest it has ever been: 6%. Over the course of the last ten years its growth has been gently lowered from the previous 8% down to the current 6%. Although there is a clear downward trend (and as their economy reaches maturity the percentage will no doubt lower) I believe a sudden drop to 4% or less would be too much of a shock to the markets and rock faith in the Chinese economy. The narrative at the moment is centred around China's strength and their rapid tackling of COVID-19. They are increasingly seen as an authority in the handling of the outbreak and their figures indicate they have almost fully contained it. Meanwhile, the outbreak in other countries are only just beginning, sliding up the exponential curve, and are soon to overwhelm many healthcare systems. While other countries will talk of unity and hard times, I think the Chinese messaging will be more around recovery and strength amidst disaster everywhere else. (For anyone looking for the data for this question, go to this link http://data.stats.gov.cn/english/easyquery.htm?cn=B01 -- you will need to go to the LHS of the page and click on "National Accounts" and then "Indices of Gross Domestic Product (preceding year=100), Current Quarter")

Disruption in China has continued, but now markets for Chinese goods are getting disrupted too. Chinese imports are disrupted too. With a highly entangled supply chain, problems anywhere can become a Chinese problem.
Most predictions are gloomy, but I heard somewhere production was back up to 90%.

China appears to be honest in its first two months' economic reports. Dateline 3-16-2020 China’s Business Activity Turns Broadly Negative for First Time
Business activity, for the first time on record, turned broadly negative, as home and retail sales, construction activity and factory output all fell China's economy recorded unprecedented falls in activity during the first two months of 2020, sending unemployment to a record 5.7% last month. -- https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-shutdowns-deliver-a-punch-to-chinas-economic-gut-11584344160

I'm hedging my bets. I'm not as confident as others that the government will report "horrible" (i.e. <4%) Q1 results.
I'll follow @chwang and rationale, take the pain in the Q1 numbers so recovery can be demonstrated in Q2.

Virus outbreak is reached the rest of the world, especially the US which imports lots of Chinese products.  With its large trading partner struggling with the virus, China cannot recover so quickly economically even if its factories start to be running again.

Little suggests more than 5.5%.  Current consensus suggests Q2 bounce back but that seems to assume end to coronavirus impact - not clear in my opinion. Forecast starts with current prediction but dials it back to reflect pessimism about direction of travel for Coronavirus. Update: Finally they contained it but at a tremendous cost

China is now reporting huge disruptions to economy. Domestic car sales down nearly 80% in 1st quarter. Factories were largely idled d/t combination of Lunar New Year + COVID19-related quarantines. https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-crushes-china-car-sales-11583996034?mod=hp_lista_pos4

Dateline 3-11-2020 Customs data shows that China’s exports shrank by 17.2 per cent in January and February combined due to coronavirus’ impact
China had postponed January’s data release, instead combining the first two months of the year -- https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3074060/coronavirus-chinas-exports-and-imports-plummeted-january-and

There are signs that China is normalising, so maybe 4 weeks of more normal growth  (6%), but 8 weeks of zero or event negative growth.  But, China also can nudge the numbers.  Going to make a much stronger call for a weak Q1, but rebound into Q2.

There's a consensus that China has taken a big hit this quarter, but I've seen conflicting information regarding what this hit might look like in terms of growth, so for now I've spread my probability across the 3 worst cases.

Need to update this forecast with new information. China's Purchasing Managers Indices (PMI) in February are around 35, down 30% from January [1].  Assuming that PMI stays at 35 in March, the average PMI for 2020 Q1 is 40, a reduction of 20% from the PMI in 2019.  Using this reduction on the expected 6% GDP growth for Q1 (before covid-19) produces 4.8% growth with the impact of outbreak. Lombard Odier, a Swiss Private Bank provided the latest forecast for China's Q1 GDP growth.  It is reduced by 35% to 3.9% [2].  With the Chinese factories reach only 60% of their capacity early March, as reported by South China Morning Post [3], this low GDP growth is believable. I am drastically adjusting my forecast.   [1]  http://www.stats.gov.cn/english/PressRelease/202003/t20200302_1729254.html
[2]  https://www.lombardodier.com/files/live/sites/loportail/files/news/2020/February/20200214/ISB_Coronavirus%20impact%20on%20China%20and%20EM_2020.02.14-media.pdf
[3] https://www.scmp.com/news/china/money-wealth/article/3065082/coronavirus-imf-again-cuts-2020-china-growth-forecast-covid

-By default, assume I'll get increasingly pessimistic as Q1 ends and recovery seems far away. 
-16 of the ~ 28 forecasts I've seen for this number have all been revised to < 4% - UOB, S&P Global Ratings, Bloomberg Economics, ANZ, Nomura, Barclays, Pantheon Macroeconomics, Goldman Sachs, Standard Chartered, Citi, UBS, Reuters poll, Nomura, Song Xiaowu (former president of the China Society of Economic Reform, a state-backed think tank), Oxford Economics. OECD forecasting -0.5% GDP growth globally for Q1.[1]
OECD forecasts (as with most GDP estimates) can be way off, but given China is the epicentre of this GDP decline and is 15% of global GDP, it seems unlikely they're _that_ far off. https://www.axios.com/coronavirus-shrink-global-gdp-b7b62247-1aac-4b83-8d25-a25a14a2d4aa.html
Assume the worst. Commerce appears to be stabilizing and new cases are getting to be fewer by the day.

Accurate chinese economic statistics are difficult to obtain. The government's drastic forced quarantines appear to have slowed the rate of spread but at the cost of severe domestic & international economic disruption. This has affected both supply-side (fewer parts + fewer workers = fewer products) and demand-side (health concerns by rest of world = decreased demand for non-essential products = fewer imports). Based on prior epidemics, this slowdown may be sudden. https://www.scmp.com/news/china/money-wealth/article/3065082/coronavirus-imf-again-cuts-2020-china-growth-forecast-covid
https://hbr.org/2020/03/what-coronavirus-could-mean-for-the-global-economy?utm_medium=email&utm_source=newsletter_daily&utm_campaign=dailyalert_activesubs&utm_content=signinnudge&referral=00563&deliveryName=DM71358
@User01's bloomberg article is best source I've seen so far https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-04/economists-cut-china-s-growth-forecast-on-coronavirus-impact

Average of some economic forecasts comes below 4% - there is a round-up of them here: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-04/economists-cut-china-s-growth-forecast-on-coronavirus-impact - even if coronavirus comes under control in China, weak global demand will dampen any pickup.
Increased conviction on below 4% GDP reading, given data points such as daily coal consumption and air pollution remain far below levels seen in the last few years.

"The economic fallout from the deadly coronavirus may cause a 6% contraction in China’s first-quarter gross domestic product, according to Pacific Investment Management Co. The GDP contraction, which would be at a quarterly annualized rate, would push down year-on-year growth to 3%, compared with 6% expansion last year, Nicola Mai, a portfolio manager and head of sovereign credit research in Europe, and Tiffany Wilding, a U.S. economist, wrote in a blog post published on Friday. The impact of this will be felt around the globe as China accounts for a quarter of worldwide manufacturing activity, they said." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-29/coronavirus-may-cause-6-contraction-in-china-s-gdp-pimco-says
Data integrity is still the issue, but as of early March, recovery is not underway.
There's zero doubt that actual growth was negative, by a lot. The question is what will they report.

Updating Q1 estimates. Chinese manufacturing PMI fell to a record low 35.7 in February, even lower than the figure seen during the depths of the financial crisis. Non-manufacturing PMI plummeted to an all time low of 29.6 from 54.1. There is the potential for political smoothing of China’s economic data, but the fact that the National Bureau of Statistics published record low PMI figures suggest it is not trying to gloss over the figures. Therefore I am substantially increasing the probability of a below 4% GDP rate of growth.

A sign that China may be willing to report bad economic news: Dateline 3-1-2020 China’s February manufacturing activity -- reported on Saturday -- plunged to its the lowest level on record.... China’s manufacturing purchasing managers’ index plunged to 35.7 in February from 50 the previous month, according to data released by the National Bureau of Statistics, much lower than the median estimate of economists. The non-manufacturing gauge also fell to 29.6, its lowest ever. Both were well below 50, which denotes contraction. -- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-01/no-place-to-hide-for-markets-looking-for-central-bank-salvation
Adjusting based on latest PMI data
- adjusted for PMI data counterbalanced by China 2020 target/goal + probability of 'data management'
Hattip to @schier1 for stating my rationale - bias towards the lower buckets.

Chinese PMI numbers for february just released showed the worst reading ever. With the economy still running some 40% below normal levels today the first quarter will be a disaster. Adjusting numbers accordingly.
Tough one. The dilemma for Chinese govt is the need to appear strong at a time where most people will know it is highly unlikely.

Update - many companies still have people working from home and travel restrictions remain in place. Coworkers with Chinese family report high isolation of everybody continuing outside of main infection loci.

Passenger traffic rose to 15.9m on Feb 25, with DoD growth at a reasonable 3.3% (vs. 4.0% on Feb 24, and an average of 2.6% in the previous 7 days), suggesting improving return-to-work traffic. Among people who left tier-1 and tier-2 cities during the two weeks before LNY, 49% have returned (vs. 47% on Feb 24). Meanwhile, intra-city traffic congestion was still 30% lower than comparable weekdays in 2019 (vs. -27% YoY on Feb 24 and an average of -30% YoY post Feb 9). Therefore indicating to me that while there are improvements, it is very slow. Several provinces have de-escalated emergency response levels over night (5 in total).  Total provinces that have de-escalated emergency response levels currently at 44% of national GDP vs 33% on Feb 25th. This is moving in the right direction however, over 50% of the country’s GDP still at the escalated emergency levels.  Various stimulus measures put in place to support the economy were announced on Feb 25th (VAT cuts, etc). But I think this will take time to flow through. Therefore moving my estimates towards the 4-4.5% level.

Reaffirming forecast. Actually growth will be negative. The question is what will be reported. i don't have a good way to think through this question because 1) the outside view is very clear that the Chinese govt has a long history of reporting bogus numbers, never below ~4%, normally ~6%. but 2) this is clearly an unusual circumstance and everyone in the country knows that the economy is at a standstill so the inside view might be the way to go. => Hedging my bets.
Zhang Anyuan says that in Feb they contracted by 12% and can reach 0% year-to-year by three months. Other sources seem to confirm this. I will go with direction for now.
they'll keep it a percentage point under current

I'm aware that SARS cut "only" 0.5-1.0% off Chinese annual growth. Still I'm betting this is a lot more impactful. I'm going out on a limb here with a more contractionary prediction.  Check out this article: 
https://www.economist.com/leaders/2020/02/13/how-chinas-coronavirus-epidemic-could-hurt-the-world-economy (subscription required)  Here are some quotes / factoids from the article: 
"China has slowed its advance only by severely limiting people’s movement and closing businesses. If the government were to relax these controls too hastily, progress could stall or even go into reverse" 
"Provinces accounting for more than 90% of Chinese exports have kept factories either shut or running at low capacity since January 31st, when the lunar new-year holiday was due to end" 
"Coal consumption is more than a third lower than the average for this time of year"
Property sales are down by more than 90%
Starbucks has shut half its 4,000-plus cafés in China
tourists, who spend $250bn a year on overseas travel, are staying at home
Hyundai has halted some car production in South Korea because parts are short. So has Nissan in Japan
"Facebook has stopped taking orders for its new virtual-reality headset and Nintendo has delayed shipments of new gaming devices. Foxconn, which makes smartphones for Apple and Huawei, has restarted its factories but with skeletal staffing. And these are just the brands you have heard of."
"China churns out a third of the world’s chemicals, half of its lcd screens and two-thirds of its polyester. Companies that think they are isolated from China could be in for a surprise"
Will probably skip by 0.3% to 0.5% but bounce back when factories and businesses reopen. Government will also do what it takes to stimulate recovery from the epidemic
173 million Chinese migrant workers sitting at home for 6 weeks.

Disasters aren't always bad for GDP, but in this case it seems people have largely stopped consuming, travelling or producing.  Any growth at all would be amazing. How PMI can be running in positive territory is just incredible: https://tradingeconomics.com/china/composite-pmi I think the major risk to the forecast is fiddled data or 4q sales being recorded in 1q
A very difficult forecast as Jan was little impacted, but Feb and March are walloped.
Immediate implications with coronavirus, including shuttering of businesses

Economists polled by Reuters between 7-13 February said they expected China's economic growth to slump to 4.5% in the first quarter of 2020, down from 6% in the previous quarter – the slowest pace since the financial crisis. https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/19/coronavirus-morgan-stanley-economic-forecasts-for-chinas-growth.html

further adjusting my estimates downwards.  The Baidu Migration Index suggests that less than 40% of people that left tier 1 and key tier 2 cities for LNY have returned (vs. 100% at this point last year).  The daily power coal consumption of the six major power generation groups – has remained 43-45% lower than the same period last year post LNY. i see room for further downgrades
Due to Covid19 and continuing US trade war.
Think will be major slump cause of fall in productivity

https://www.google.com/amp/s/mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKBN20801H Growth will be impacted but I believe it will be slightly higher than economic predictions because of huge state investment in stockpiling and containment efforts

China´s GDP growth has remained in about 6-7% for last three years. In Q1Y2019 it was 6.4% and Q4Y2020 6.1%. Before Coronavirus outbreak predict for 2020 GDP growth was 5.5%-6%. SARS had serious impact on China´s GDP 20 years ago (growth in one Q 2 points down). Many global financial institutions have reduced them whole year GDP growth prediction of China for 0.2-0.5% due to coronavirus. If we consider that outbreak might affect to just H1 it would mean 0.4%-1% decrease in GDP growth. It is noticeable that there was likely only small impact  on numbers of January. Sources

A Feb. 7-13 Reuters poll released yesterday of 40 economists based in mainland China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Europe and the United States predicts that China’s annual economic growth in the first quarter will be 4.5% (median of forecasts) [1]. A first-quarter forecast released by HSBC this past Thursday estimates 4.1% growth [2].  If we give the Reuters poll forecast three times the weight we give the HSBC forecast (since the Reuters poll is already aggregating the predictions of 40 economists), we arrive at 4.4%. [2] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-gdp/hsbc-cuts-china-economic-growth-forecast-on-coronavirus-impact-idUSKBN2071T5

Base rate: China's GDP dropped from 11.1% in Q1 to 9.1% in Q2 in 2003 during the SARS outbreak [1].  Many economists attributed this 2 percentage point (pp) drop to the effect of SARS to China's economy.  China's GDP forecast for Q1 2020 is 5.8 to 6.0%.   One way to forecast the impact of Covid-19 is to subtract 2 pp from the forecast 5.8-6.0%, yielding 3.8-4% GDP growth for Q1 2020.  Using the 2 pp seems to be too extreme because 2 pp drop in the 6% GDP growth is more than 30% drop, as compared with the same 2 pp in the 11% GDP growth during the SARS outbreak (a merely 18% drop). If you use the 18% drop, this will produce a basic rate of 4.8-4.9% GDP growth for Q1. S&P and other financial organizations [2] [3] have forecasted the impact of Covid-19 on the Chinese economy.  For the Q1 2020 GDP growth, the numbers center around 5.0%, with an outlier of 4%.  Their forecasts make it a bit tricky for this question because the boundary between two of the baskets is 5.0%.  I will give the 4.5 to less than 5% basket a slightly higher probability due to the base rate. [1]  http://data.stats.gov.cn/english/index.htm
[2]  https://www.reuters.com/article/brief-sp-says-estimates-coronavirus-will-idUSFWN2AB11M
[3]  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/05/china-gdp-2020-banks-trim-forecasts-amid-outbreak.html

Q1 will take the brunt of the economic impact. After the extension of the lunar year holidays, the economic activity restarted but very slowly. While factories are still running, some at slow speed, other sectors including transport, tourism, entertainment are heavily impacted. The fear factor and drastic containment measures limited consumption. E-commerce could partly compensate, but deliveries are limited by the situation so even this is actually slowed down. GDP growth in Q1 could be reduced by almost 2% if the situation is under control by mid- to end of March.

The SARS outbreak caused a decrease from 11.1% GDP to 9.1% for the next three months.  This was nearly twenty years ago. There is always a question around how fudged the GDP growth rate for China is; will the government try to boost the numbers to shrug off the outbreak's effect on China's economy?  I seriously doubt we'll see a number below 5.0%.
Little signs of business normalisation based on traffic data and coal consumption daily data. Therefore reducing estimates for growth downwards slightly.

Given the decrease in China's GDP growth rate from 14.2% in 2007 to 6.5% in 2018 (World Bank), I predict that this trend will continue, with a more drastic decrease expected due to the corona virus. I forecast, with 50% probability that the GDP growth rate will fall to between 5 and 5.5% for the first quarter of 2020, as the corona virus will likely be rising. Due to coronavirus' impact on the economy (consumer purchases, transportation, manufacturing, shipping) the GDP will likely feel the brunt of this troubling time for China.  https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.MKTP.KD.ZG?locations=CN

China wants to maintain the appearance that they have this outbreak under control (regardless of reality) for domestic and international reasons. They need to maintain the mandate of heaven and prevent panic from spreading, as well as quell investor and industry fears, despite having closed down areas that accounted for 80% of their GDP and 90% of their exports last year [1]. Given China's history of manipulating its numbers (the CCP is most likely manipulating the reported numbers of infected and dead as well) and their strong interest and culture of saving face, they will give the appearance that their GDP has only somewhat slowed down in Q1 [2]. Q2 and Q3 reports will most likely be closer in line with the actual GDP growth, but will still be exaggerated. Furthermore, the 2019-nCov affects their standing geopolitically, giving them less leverage in their trade war with the United States, emboldening Hong Kong protests, harming the Silk Road, hindering investment in Africa, and providing ample opportunities for intelligence agencies to foster dissent among the population. Manufacturers will be spooked into diversifying their supply chain to prevent future delays in case of another event like this and China will want to quell their fears through putting up a strong front. China will report a dip, but nothing dramatic that cannot be quickly overcome.
 Overall, China has little reason to report the actual numbers and every reason to inflate their numbers in hopes of maintaining their economic and geopolitical momentum. To not do so would be political and economic suicide. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/01/coronavirus-more-of-china-extend-shutdown-accounting-for-80percent-of-gdp.html
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-03-08/china-s-gdp-growth-pace-was-inflated-for-nine-years-study-finds

So, to avoid reporting numbers that would reflect a worrisome trend of decelerating growth - and the negative conversations that would ensue - the provinces can be counted on to be generous in their estimates of Q1 2020 production in the manner described in the South China Morning Post article. 
Which is why I band an 80%+ likelihood of "reported" growth ranging from 4.5% to 5.5% in Q1 2020, with 60%+ likelihood that "reported" growth will be north of 5%.

In the last week, due to the stabilisation of new cases of infection outside Hubei (377 for Feb 11th vs 370 on Feb 10th), policymakers have begun to call for an orderly restart of production. New cases growth within Hubei province also down from previous days. Scenario analysis:
1.	0.5-1ppt hit to quarterly GDP under a scenario where outbreak peaks in Feb/March and quick production normalisation after the Chinese holiday. 
2.	1-1.5ppt if more regions take up phased production resumption like Hangzhou and Zhengzhou. This means another 2-3 weeks interruption to production compared with normal years. 
3.	1.5-2ppt. Prolonged suspension of factories, travel restrictions.  Number 1 is the least likely based on current data (daily power coal consumption little changed in recent days and way down vs pre-LNY levels, nationwide passenger traffic also little changed in recent days indicating a slow restart to factory restarts). Number 2 appears most likely to me. There will be downward pressure on this and upward on scenario 3 if data such as passenger traffic remains at current low levels. Pre-virus Q1 consensus was +6% Q1 real GDP growth. Scenario 1 is 5.5-6% Q1 growth. In scenario 2 the range is therefore 4.5-5% growth. Scenario 3 is therefore 4-4.5% growth. As discussed scenario 2 is currently the most likely outcome in my view.

Based on how closed China is to reveal information internally and externally, and based on the historical growth they'd reported, my estimation is that they will comply announcing 1Q growth independently of the corona virus status, at least for this quarter.

Q1 figure could end up stronger than Q2 - if the rate at which the virus spreads has not yet flat-lined (unlikely by recent headline figures)  The full impact may not be recognised through the numbers until Q2 when one could see the real drop in productivity and wider economic activity.  For now the baseline is a drop of between 0.5% and 1% hit to GDP - Last Q4 in December 2019 GDP figure was 6% - matching the Q3 figure.... the New Year annual drop off in activity in some parts of the economy is now amplified due to the recent outbreak - restriction of movement from a large number of people will have an impact - the disruption to trade and other sectors within the Chinese economy that will also be badly hit in many regions across the country but I expect that to be seen coming through even more severely in the Q2 numbers - in the short term tourism and recreational economic activities (which have been growing incredibly fast) will show real declines - only caveat to the above is the Chinese govt's trusted ability to consistently manipulate all the figures to avoid causing short term panic.....

For the past eight quarter’s, China GDP growth rate has averaged between 6% and 7%, flattening out at 6% in Q3 and Q4 of 2019. However, with the outbreak of the coronavirus, China’s GDP growth will most likely slow as many workers are facing quarantine and several supply chains have halter. In 2014 with the outbreak of Ebola Africa, Guinea saw a sharp drop in GDP growth from 1.1% at the start of the year to 0.1% by the start of 2015. Similarly, Libera saw a drop in GDP growth from 7.1% at the end of 2013 to 0.7% in 2014 to -1.6% in 2016. (All statistics from tradingeconomics.com)

The extended holiday is over, but returning to work is not uniform. Supply chains will be difficult to synch in the short term. Hattip to @orchidny for analysis. I am assuming this is an easy time to justify reporting bad news.

I've had a close look at the data for the last 18 quarters. The annual change has been dropping steadily since Q2 in 2018 (after having fluctuated between 106.8 and 107.0 for about 3 years) at an average rate of 0.18 per quarter until it stalled at 106.0 in Q3 and Q4 2019. If the previous trend picks up, it drops to about 105.8, or possibly skips to 105.6. I don't see any realistic scenario where it jumps well below 105.5. I don't really believe the Chinese will report a blip associated with the coronavirus, at least not in Q1.

China's GDP grew 6.1% in 2019, their slowest rate of economic growth since 1990.
Before the onset of the 2019nCov, the 6.0 baseline figure came in just below the IMF's forecast of 6.2% for 2019. Q3 and Q4 of 2019 had the lowest growth rates of the year at 6%.  Looking at the SARS epidemic of 2003 as a reference, it knocked 2 full percentage points off China’s economic growth, which dipped from 11.1% in Q1 of 2003 to 9.1% the following quarter. With the outbreak contained, growth recovered to 10% in Q3.  But the numbers of people infected and the magnitude of the quarantine is muchlarger.

"In the almost 20 years since SARS, China’s importance in the global economy has grown exponentially. In 2003, the types of industries that were most affected by government-imposed bans on travel and other measures to contain the outbreak—such as retail, restaurants, entertainment, and tourism—accounted for 42% of GDP. Since then, services industries’ share of GDP has risen to 54%. Back in 2003, China’s GDP was an insignificant 4% of the global total. That share now stands at 17%, which means the effect could be bigger." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-31/the-coronavirus-is-more-dangerous-for-the-economy-than-sars
Corona Virus will hurt but gov will report a dent but not a change that cannot be recovered from.
Integration of their economy means a huge slowdown for a bit. Trade tensions were already slowing growth and now internal growth will be hit.
Hattip @chwang for comparison with SARS impact although I think the impact will be felt sooner than his analysis.

The virus has caused a sudden stop of the Chinese economie at the end of january. The economy is paralyzed right now and restarting it takes time. It will take weeks from now to operate ports, airports and production processes at the speed it was before the virus. This is likely to shave off much more of China GDP when compared to the impact of SARS. The virus has not peaked yet so in my view it takes longer for factories to return to normal or risk accelerating the virus.

SARS decreased China's 2003 GDP by 0.5-1%. nCoV is more contagious and disruptive. The Chinese economy is now much more service-oriented and reliant on supply chains for both domestic & foreign trade. Many nations have imposed travel bans to/from China. Chinese citizens are voluntarily reducing domestic consumption due to voluntary isolation. More importantly, there is growing fear and distrust of the government among the Chinese public. Based on the long incubation time and difficulty in controlling spread, I do not think nCoV will be controlled anytime soon. Thus, the contagion of fear negatively impact the Chinese economy (and worldwide). 
I believe nCoV will result in an drop by >3% this year, but Q1 2020 may be too soon to feel the full impact. Therefore, I think it will most likely result in a index of around 5% growth, with a significant possibility that this may turn into a full-blown national panic.

Factories are working only part time.  Stores are closed or working under limited hours (I bought a bike yesterday and was told they are only allowed to open 2 hours/day).  People are staying in doors and avoiding going out.

I'm counting on the lack of transparency evidenced in the suppressing news about the existence of the virus, and then its spread, to carry though into financial performance estimates.
Current government estimates of 6%+ annual growth for 2020 will likely remaining silent on any Q1 adjustments.
We will probably have to rely on anecdotal evidence of supply chain shifts in order to infer a move away from official Q1 GDP estimates.
First off - let's see if China opens for business on Monday - or tells everyone over the weekend to continue to stay home.
Along those lines -when SBUX and MCD re-open - then we can guess the quarantine is effectively over, and can then get more reliable non-government estimates for Q1's attenuated growth.
